name: prunus-domestica-subsp-insititia-shropshire-prune
edibility: The small to medium sized fruit has blue skin and yellow flesh. It is said the flesh has an astringent taste which makes it more suitable to make jams, canning or preserving. Ripens from August to early September.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: The small to medium sized fruit has blue skin and yellow flesh. Ripens from August to early September.
flower-description: The white, clustered flowers bloom in April.
leaf-description: The green elliptic leaves have fine tooth on the margin.
poison-symptoms: Stems, leaves, seeds contain cyanide, particularly toxic in the process of wilting: brick red mucous membranes, dilated pupils, difficulty breathing, panting, shock.
